Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: An Interdisciplinary Study of Hyperdiverse Endophytic Fungi and Their Function in Boreal Forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
As major sources of ecological and evolutionary innovation, symbioses drive genome evolution, ecological diversification, and speciation - and thus shape all dimensions of the diversity of life. The goal of this study is to examine the taxonomic, genetic, and functional diversity of endophytes, one of Earth's most prevalent, but least-understood, groups of symbionts. Endophytic fungi are found within healthy above-ground tissues of all plants (and in lichens as "endolichenic fungi"), including crop- and forage plants, and peak in their phylogenetic diversity in boreal forests, an imperiled ecosystem of immense global importance. This interdisciplinary study will develop a novel biodiversity informatics pipeline to discover, evaluate, and describe new species of boreal endophytes at multiple spatial and phylogenetic scales around the circumboreal belt. Culture-based and culture-free surveys will yield the largest sample of endophytic fungi to date, setting the stage for testing novel hypotheses regarding the evolution of ecological modes in the Ascomycota, the most species-rich fungal phylum; developing new model systems for evaluating, for the first time, the functional diversity of endophyte communities; and elucidating the genetic mechanisms shaping that diversity, including mobile genetic elements, endohyphal microbial symbionts, and genome evolution. Data will be managed and released through an integrated system built around the Suite of Nucleotide Analysis Programs (SNAP) and made public through a dedicated web portal, EnDoBiodiversity.org.

This highly integrative project also seeks to promote diversity in science for high school students, STEM teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars at scales ranging from local outreach at four universities to widespread international collaboration. Hosting of international researchers, leadership of international workshops, and development of international symposia will synergize fungal taxonomy and molecular systematics while boosting rates of species descriptions to a level never reached before and fostering novel collaborations in the study of fungal symbionts. Building and sharing of novel biodiversity informatics tools will be complemented by development and deposition of permanent fungal culture collections and extensive molecular sequence datasets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although the global diversity of fungi is estimated to far exceed five million species, mycologists have described only ca. 100,000 species so far. The disparity largely reflects an immense but invisible richness of species that is hidden within other organisms through symbiosis. As major sources of ecological and evolutionary innovation, symbioses drive genome evolution, ecological diversification, and speciation, thereby shaping all dimensions of the diversity of life. The over-arching goal of this project was to study one of the planet’s most prevalent but least-understood symbioses: that of hyperdiverse endophytic fungi (endophytes), which occur within healthy above-ground tissues of all plants (and in lichens as endolichenic fungi) in biomes ranging from tropical rainforests to Arctic tundra. Hyperdiverse, ecologically important, evolutionarily dynamic, and representing an under-explored trove of taxonomic, genetic, and functional diversity, endophytes peak in phylogenetic richness in boreal forests, an imperiled ecosystem of global importance.

We sampled endophytic and endolichenic fungal communities from ten distinct plant species and ten lichen species from seven localities throughout the circumboreal belt (USA, Canada, Sweden and Russia). We also sampled plants and lichens along a transect crossing the entire boreal belt (up to the tree limit) and along an east-west oriented transect of the same length, i.e., ≈ 1300 km, in Canada.

We discovered that the type of symbiosis, i.e., endolichenic vs endophytic, influences fungal communities more than geographical distance and local abiotic conditions. Many endophytes were placed in lineages previously not known for endophytism. The great majority of endophytes appear to represent novel species, but inferences are limited by potential gaps in public databases.  We also discovered at least three new orders of Fungi demonstrating the disconnect between what is known and the hyperdiverse fungal biodiversity awaiting to be discovered.

To explore the function of these fungi in plants, we studied fungal communities in the living and decomposing parts of a model moss system and we re-associated fungi isolated in pure culture with their moss host in the laboratory. We found that active fungal communities are structured according to the gradient of host senescence (i.e., top green and healthy layer, middle dying portion, and bottom partially decomposed layer). In general, Ascomycota (sac fungi) are dominant in the living (top) plant layer, while Basidiomycota (e.g., mushrooms) are more abundant in the dead (bottom) parts of the moss. However, several fungal species can be found in all layers of this senescent gradient and can switch between endophytism (when interacting with the healthy portion of the moss) and a decomposing lifestyle (when interacting with dead tissues of the same moss).

New online software (portal) was generated for this project (Tree-Based Alignment Selector [T-BAS] toolkit; http://tbas.hpc.ncsu.edu/start), which enables web-based placement and visualization of unknown DNA sequences using both BLAST and phylogeny-aware methods. We hope this portal will enable taxonomists to discover and describe new species of fungi at a much faster rate than previously while reducing redundancy in the discovery process.

This project supported the training of two female postdoctoral researchers, one of which is now an Assistant Professor at the University of California, Santa Barbara; one Asian (Taiwan) female Ph.D. student, one female undergraduate student, one undergraduate male student from Colombia, and one female high school student. Six symposia were organized as part of this project: Two at national meetings (Mycological Society of America, 2011 and 2016) and four at international congresses (Symbiosis 2012 [Poland], International Mycological congress [IMC10] 2014 [Thailand], Ascomycota Workshop 2015 [The Netherlands], and the Eight Congress of the International Association for Lichenology [IAL8] 2016 [Finland]). Two workshops on fungal endophytes were organized for high school students at the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics.  We also organized two one-day exhibits at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences in Raleigh, NC (2016 and 2017).

This grant generated 12 scientific articles and three additional manuscripts will be published in 2017. The website endobiodiversity.org was dedicated to this project. At that website we described the project and reported our research and outreach activities. This website is also accessible directly from the home page of the Lutzoni lab (lutzonilab.org) where all publications from the Lutzoni lab are listed.
